I didn't find this game very fun. Not very balanced champions, slow and with an unintuitive shop drags this game down below other MOBAs in my eyes. I didn't play for very long, but the time I did play was even more frustrating than playing league or HOTS. 
The tower aggro seems to have no rhyme or reason, and when you start taking tower damage, the tower seems to gain infinite range, champions who are melee seem to have ranged attacks, the graphics are poor and the game is just bland. 
I may try to pick this game up later, but for now, it's going in the garbage section of my library.

I hope anyone who likes first person shooters tries this game because its a lot of fun when you understand how the classes work and how they function. The only problems I have with this game is barely any new updates and some very minor bugs but besides that this game is a beautiful classic and I think everyone should try it at least once.

The only thing I didn't like was being forced to sacrifice a friend and not having a reasonable alternative to avoid it, because even after using a certain needle that reverses the effect, the friend doesn't return for a final dialogue. I found it harsh and unnecessary; in my opinion, the tarnished are unethical for accepting this, and the game promotes it as the right choice (forcing the creators' vision onto the player, and not giving them a real choice).


Só não gostei de uma coisa, sermos obrigado a sacrificar uma amigo(a) e não ter uma alternativa razoável para evitar isso, pois mesmo após usar uma certa agulha que reverte o efeito, a amiga(o) nao volta para um diálogo final. Achei pesado e desnecessário, na minha opiniao o tarnished é anti-ético por aceitar isso, e o jogo prega como escolha certa (forçando visão dos criadores para o jogador, e não dá escolha real para ele).

prompt:

Write a review for the game "Counter-Strike 2".
Target rating: 3/10.

Constraints:
- Length: 100 to 140 words
- Mention exactly 2 negative points and 1 positive point
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
I’m genuinely surprised that a free-to-play competitive shooter can have such poor performance.

For context: I’m playing on a 4K monitor with a budget GPU (Intel Arc B580). Even so, getting unstable ~60 FPS on the lowest settings, with FSR enabled in Performance mode (50% scaling, effectively rendering at 1080p), is very disappointing. This happens in both DX11 and Vulkan modes.

Unfortunately, this has been one of the most unpleasant gaming experiences I’ve had in a long time.

For comparison, Valorant runs flawlessly on the same system: I can easily achieve 250+ FPS at max settings without any upscaling, and I genuinely enjoy playing it.

It’s a real shame. I don’t need cutting-edge visuals or complex technical features—I just want a smooth, playable experience to enjoy the game with friends from time to time. Sadly, that feels unnecessarily difficult right now.

I really enjoy playing Counter-Strike 2. The game feels smooth and updated, but it still keeps the classic Counter-Strike gameplay I love. The graphics look better, the maps feel refreshed, and the gunplay is very satisfying once you get used to it.

I especially like how the smokes work now because they make each round feel more strategic. Every match feels competitive and rewarding, whether I’m playing seriously or just having fun with friends. CS2 keeps me coming back, and it’s definitely one of my favorite shooters to play.

Write a review for the game "Team Fortress 2".
Target rating: 9/10.

Constraints:
- Length: 100 to 140 words
- Mention exactly 2 positive points and 1 negative point
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
South American valve servers have almost no cheaters of any kind.

This will always be the best "hero" shooter, casual fun environment + comedic in voice acting and game design that are alien to modern games.
No stoic military heros; no heros that couldn't bear ill will against a mosquito; no evil heros of tragic backstory that might be just misunderstood, but instead a bunch of human psycopaths bearing a cartoony levels of hate and love towards each other.
No ultimates to cause a "Q" kitchen sink standoff; only cooldown is running out of loaded ammo; no hero sharing a role with each other; no role-locking yourself; 9 heros with sidegrades will always be more insteresting and balanced than 40+ hero rosters even when there is no real update in a decade.
Not to mention how mechanically deep some tricks can be.
It is a very old game, and still the best in the genre.

Ten Years ago, this game had the prime of its life ripped from it. Gun Mettle started skins, poor balancing that would influence Jungle Inferno, and "Competitive/Casual."
Ever since then I've struggled to quit this game like a drug until today when I realize the maps are all piddled out by the same crew of folks, there hasn't been any additions outside of "Funny flashy hat haha pay me for it" and its gotten toxic. Every match is a spawn camp fest or you end up removed for "Friendly killing." No offense, but being spawncamped an entire round and then joining another match to continue to be spawncamped because of poor developer oversight on the basis of bad or outright malicious players, it ends in full sweeps without ever getting out the door. 
Valve, sunset this disaster. You've modified and tampered with it so much it isn't its original form. It's a shell. And I'd rather not keep pretending. 
Move on, the hype died long ago with Jungle Inferno.

Review:
completion:
At first I hated it and uninstalled it before finishing it. I tried a second time and hated it again. Then Cyberpunk became what it is today and entered my top 3 favorite games of all time.

The graphics are simply unreachable for any other game—light-years ahead, especially if you use mods. Nothing comes close.

The city is breathtaking, and even after hundreds of hours I’m still discovering locked doors and secret places I’ve never seen before.

It’s true the game isn’t perfect (perfection doesn’t exist), but thanks to the enthusiasm of a huge modding community, if you’re patient you’ll find the mods that fit you, making your Cyberpunk experience unique and personal.

If the game is still so popular and so heavily modded, it’s because of how the developers turned around a product that launched in a disastrous state and made it the masterpiece it is now.

See you in Night City.

Review:
completion:
Right off the bat, "Cybrepunk: 2077" feels like "Grand Theft Auto 4" had a baby with "High On Life" except it is missing the best parts of both games. I would say some of the gameplay feels half baked. If you're looking for a solid parkour engine, look elsewhere, like "Dying Light." The combat is enjoyable, but broken in favor of the player even on hard difficulty.
There's so many more interactions that just beg to be present. Dates and engagements with friends and spouses. Tons of interactivity seems missing. GTA4 really sold this years ago.
The characters and story are what sell here. This game is on track to be the "Mass Effect" of our age.
Tons, tons, and tons of good opportunity here. The devs just needed more time. Real eye candy story piece, but I absolutely loved it.

I spawned in this cave basically half-naked with a club, feeling confident for about two seconds before a giant spider folded me like laundry. Some mysterious lady saved me, which was great because clearly I needed adult supervision.

Finally made it outside, took a breath, and immediately got run over by some golden dude on a horse who looked like he pays taxes in pain and suffering.

10/10 game. Painful, disrespectful, magical. Would absolutely get clapped again.

Review:
completion:
Incredible depth and nuance with high skill ceilings and the most integrated and expansive client of any moba.   The game feels very premium outside of annoying bugs in the game viewer. 

The community also has a high skill level (creating a pretty high skill floor) which can make even unranked games overwhelming for new players.

If you can make it through the steep learning curve you will experience a tactical moba far beyond the rest of the field.

I recommend turning on anonymous mode when starting out to mute other players, the community is toxic and obnoxious towards new players.

completion: I had played this back in 2020 on ps4 when it first came out and... completion:
The Best game I have ever played.

Pros:
-Story of both the DLC and Base game has insane depth and is rich in lore.
-Gameplay is extensive and engaging, from hacking, shooting, slashing, worth multiple runthroughs.
-The world is vast and dripping in detail. Nothing feels unfinished and truly pushes the limits of an open world experience.
-Visuals are insane..

Cons
-Street NPCs sometimes feel empty. However, cyberpunk does it better than most other open world games.
-Tutorial can feel quite long and there is a learning curve, but once finished you will be helplessly immeresed.

Final Comments:
This game is the greatest available in the genre of open worlds and cyberpunk.
If you are considering this game, just give it a go!

100/100

Review:
completion:
Booting up Cyberpunk 2077 is like jacking straight into Night City’s datastream—neon-soaked streets, chrome everywhere, and vibes cranked to max like some preem Lizzy Wizzy BD. The world feels alive, chooms: corpos scheming, street thugs hustling, and fixers dropping gigs like hot data shards.

The combat? Preem. Whether you’re blasting gonks, slicing with monowires, or quickhacking enemies into flatline mode, it feels slick once you’re chromed up. The story hits hard too—full of moral gray zones and moments that make you stop and think, like a real braindance.

And the achievements? Absolute nice to grind (expect for some endings ) but nevertheless nice to spend time on them—pure nova. Each one feels like scoring serious eddies, rewarding you for exploring every dark alley and wild build Night City has to offer.

Sure, it had some rough patches back in the day, but now it runs way smoother and feels like the game it was always meant to be. If you’re into deep stories, open-world chaos, and that high-tech low-life aesthetic, this one’s worth the jack-in.

I’d totally recommend it, choom. Cyberpunk 2077 is nova-tier now—don’t sleep on it.

Write a review for the game "Counter-Strike 2".
Target rating: 9/10.

Constraints:
- Length: 100 to 140 words
- Mention exactly 2 positive points and 1 negative point
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Valve has blessed us once again—not with Half-Life 3, don’t be ridiculous—but with Counter-Strike 2, a game that proves you can, in fact, make the same experience shinier and still have everyone scream in delight (and agony).

First off, it looks gorgeous. The reflections are so realistic that I spent two minutes admiring water puddles on Mirage before getting one-tapped by someone with 300 hours in aim maps. The smoke grenades? Now volumetric, baby. They react to bullets and grenades, which means instead of providing cover, they now beautifully showcase how terrible my spray control is.

Performance-wise, the tick rate upgrade feels good—until your 17-year-old teammate starts yelling “PEEK HIM!” while your 200ms reaction time proves you are, in fact, too old for this. CS2 runs smoother, but your rank? Still the same. Valve made sure of that for emotional continuity.

The new UI looks sleek, the gun models gleam like freshly waxed sports cars, and the matchmaking queue still perfectly matches you with teammates who bought AWP and died without using it. It’s good to know some traditions are sacred.


CS:GO but in 4K and emotionally damaging in new and exciting ways.

Review:
completion:
Good game with the same issues as The Witcher 3.
Pros:
+ Good main story and side quests (sometimes)
+ Nice voiceover
+ Huge city with a lot of secrets

Cons:
- Inventory is the same mess as in The Witcher 3, hard to find anything, hard to navigate, no persistent filters, no bulk actions
- Battle gameplay is kinda average, in most cases it's just 2-click combat or plain shooter with not a lot of possibilities
- Game physics behaves super weird sometimes, stuff jumps and explodes when you loot something, bodies of enemies lie on walls or in the air, etc.
- Parkour is also totally random; sometimes a character can parkour, sometimes stops, and can't do anything, and it's not fluent in any way.
- Enemies are super aimy, can easily target me moving behind a wall. Also, sometimes they start spamming with grenades (grenades are so not needed and unnecessary in this game IMO). 
- Still a lot of issues 5 years later (enemies in walls, cars spawn upside down, can't loot sometimes)

Write a review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".
Target rating: 9/10.

Constraints:
- Length: 100 to 140 words
- Mention exactly 2 positive points and 1 negative point
- Casual, honest tone

- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
While Cyberpunk 2077 came out in a half-baked rush state, it's undeniably a fairly polished game now and definitely worth your time if not for one playthrough. Before the long form review, I'll say I've played both the main game and Phantom Liberty twice, of those I played 2/3 lifepaths; however I still have yet to complete all endings, all sidequests, and the nomad lifepath. This means that there's still a lot of side content I never finished due to burnout with the game.

So the long review? Cyberpunk 2077 is a flawed but good game that takes the hallmarks of games like GTA and attempts to put a coat of Cyberpunk paint on it, while this does mean the gameplay is fairly strong and CDPR's standard build/playstyle flexibility exists, gameplay can get stale fast in longer sessions; however this is generally made up for by great voice-acting, good to excellent environmental storytelling, and a semi-compelling main narrative. Overall I had fun with my time but definitely not a game that's endlessly replayable or repeatable. 8.5/10

*FYI Mac users, Mac port runs great barring a few bugs here and there, if you haven't already, definitely pick this one up on sale.

Write a review for the game "ELDEN RING".

- Length: 100 to 140 words

Review:
completion:
I just did not enjoy ER.

The combat is great, but the bosses are overly aggressive and are clearly designed with Spirit Ashes in mind. They hit hard, give you little to no breathing room, and have huge health pools. Without summons and soul grinding this game is probably the hardest Soulsborne game. But the summons trivialize everything and make many bosses  easily beatable within 5-6 tries. They failed to strike a balance. 

The open world is just bad. Plain and simple. It's dead, lifeless, hollow, and every synonym of these words. It was fun to explore for the first few hours, but it gets really boring real fast. There is just so much repetitiveness (reskinned bosses, reskinned catacombs, ruins, caves, etc.) that it made me stop exploring and just rush through the game so I can move on to other games I wanted to play.

The storytelling is From's weakest area, yet they decided to create an even deeper lore, make it even more cryptic compared to the other games, and combined it with a HUGE open world so the story and lore are even harder to understand. 

The level design is still good though. I'll give the game at least that. 

Thumbs down for me.

Write a review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".
Target rating: 3/10.

Constraints:
- Length: 100 to 140 words
- Mention exactly 2 negative points and 1 positive point
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
The most 6/10 game I've ever played. For all of its promises of being an RPG, you have very little meaningful choice in the story and gameplay. Quests typically have one outcome, rarely two, and the outcomes often just boil down to what kind of vendor trash weapon you get as a reward. Combat is divided into conventional gunplay, which is fine; melee combat, which is weightless and uninteresting; and quickhacks, which are useless for 50% of the game and blatantly overpowered and boring for the other 50%. 

The world has nothing to do but engage in repetitive combat encounters, side quests and main story missions are all variations of combat and stealth encounters with no interesting mix-ups to the gameplay. The writing feels like the first draft of a 9th grade edgelord's fanfiction, and all of the characters so painfully dull it actually became a chore to suffer through their cutscenes. I want to shout out Keanu Reeves in particular for giving his usual bored, monotone drawl for a 100 hour game.

Get it on sale.

    Practice or the community will hate you, also... expiriment. There are many secrets hidden in the settings you can try.
-Report players who are abusive in language or tell you to quit or uninstall. They probably feed as much as you do.

Counter-Strike: Global Offensive isn’t just a first-person shooter—it’s a timeless classic that defines competitive gaming. Free-to-play, easy to pick up but brutally hard to master, it boils down FPS fun to its purest form: tight 5v5 bomb defusal showdowns on iconic maps like Dust II and Mirage.
Every round hinges on teamwork, map knowledge, and precise weapon control—no flashy abilities, just raw skill. The satisfying crack of an AK-47, the heart-pounding rush of a 1v3 clutch, and the thrill of ranking up keep players hooked for hundreds of hours. Sure, occasional cheaters and a salty community pop up, but Prime matchmaking and a loyal fanbase smooth those edges out.
For over a decade, CS:GO has stood the test of time, cementing its status as a must-play for anyone who loves fast-paced, strategic shooters. It’s not just a game—it’s a staple of gaming culture.

Alright, I'm a new player to CS. Picked up Global Offensive in 2015 - 2016 which was the first time i'd touch any CS game. And then the current 700+ hours followed so I'll share my two cents:

CS2 is basically Global Offensive but modernized. Gameplay feels familiar enough, core mechanics are unchanged (except for the trade ups ofcourse but...yikes) and overall it's just a new way to keep our beloved GO spirit alive.

That being said, after ten years they still haven't fixed the cheater problem. At all. That is one of the few nitpicks I have against this game. Other than that, sure I'd say go ahead and play it for a few hours & see if you like it. Prime status helps with getting less cheaters but to be honest, roughly 60% of the playerbase is cheating anyways which just straight up sucks.

TL;DR CS:GO went super saiyan 2 but still has a cheater problem. Game good, Anticheat horrible. 7/10

completion:
Counter-Strike 2 feels like a fresh but familiar evolution of the classic CS experience. The new Source 2 engine brings noticeable improvements in lighting, smoke physics, and overall visuals, making the game feel more alive without losing its competitive identity.

Gunplay is still satisfying and skill-based, which longtime players will appreciate, while the updated maps and mechanics add just enough change to keep things interesting. The new smoke system is one of the best additions, adding more depth and strategy to every round.

That said, CS2 still has some issues to work on, such as optimization, bugs, and missing features compared to CS:GO. However, the core gameplay is strong, and with future updates, the game has a lot of potential.

Overall, CS2 is a solid step forward for the franchise and a promising foundation for the future of competitive FPS games.

Write a review for the game "ELDEN RING".

Constraints:
- Length: 100 to 140 words
- Mention exactly 2 negative points and 1 positive point

- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
If your goal is to have a good time and mess around with friends - the purchase of the game is a nobrainer.
if your goal is to explore and do 100% of the shit, this game will probably suit you.
If your goal is to solo it, do quest, learn the lore etc - this game is not for you. 

Sadly, the latter is the exact reason why I picked this one, and after 60h in on the second attempt at a playthrough, I got bored as fuck (got bored the 1st time, too) of running around killing mobs, looting garbage, grinding, and getting none the wiser about the world, lore, quests (had to install a mod to keep track, srsly?).

All in all, the open (but dull and essentially empty) world, supposedly brilliant writing (that is hardly present in the game), repetitiveness, 99% garbage loot, and grind eventually took it out of me.

The graphics are nice and the game world is well-designed, this much I'll admit, but if you want a good souls-like that will not bore you to hell, do yourself a favor and get LOTF2.

Review:
completion:
Elden Ring is visually extraordinary and mechanically restrictive.

The world, lore, and environmental storytelling are exceptional. The art team and narrative contributors deserve praise.

Unfortunately, the core gameplay philosophy prioritizes punishment over expression. Boss design often enforces rigid behavior, discouraging experimentation and turning mastery into memorization.

Difficulty is not the problem — lack of player agency is.

I finished the game, but the final hours felt like endurance rather than engagement. Challenge should elevate the player, not domesticate them.

A beautiful world constrained by an authoritarian design mindset.

Review:
completion:
This game is (almost) a gold standard of balance that can hold both the test of time and extreme conditions. Community tinkering and experience have pushed this game so far and the depth of the game means that almost 18 (!) years later the playerbase is still kicking and rabid as ever.

There's not much that can be said about this game that hasn't been discussed at least 3 times over, however I will still point out one of the flaws that strikes the hardest to me, that being the weapon balance.

The stock classes themselves are fine and show a lot of tweaking and thought into their designs, however some items that were added after initial release do not show this consideration, such as the Homewrecker for Pyro, the Vaccinator for Medic and also some of the weaker weapons like Sun on a Stick for Scout, Red Tape Recorder for Spy or the Eviction Notice for Heavy.

This game overall is great though, and many criticisms about game balance were unanticipated on Valve's part or are tied into the map design of popular maps added by the community.

Review:
completion:
It's not perfect but Elden Ring is a good game, has a lot going for it and can offer countless hours of immersion and gameplay.

The landscape and world is beautiful. fromsoftware did a great job building a gorgeous world to explore.

The dungeons, castles and many level designs are fantastic with depth to them and various obstacles to resolve and conquer. Many secret areas to find and places to explore.

I enjoyed a lot of the combat and the game offers you a variety of ways to dispatch your enemies from many hand to hand combat weapons, to magic or distance attacks. The game lets you get creative.

A lot of people complain the game "freezes" or stutters.  Here is the solution: The game runs at 60fps... Ensure your monitor is set to 60Hz refresh, change all nvidia settings in your panel for performance and also cap the fps at 60. Ensure all Vsync/Gsync settings are set within nvidia and on your actual display. Works flawlessly.

The game isn't perfect but it is a great game.

Review:
completion: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2023 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. I don't like shooters, I don't like American cheese and there's no way I was buying this sh1t they couldn't even be arsed finishing.  No way was I supporting a company like that.  Well I stopped being a little b1tch and did just that and bought it.  My mate gave me £10 gift card for Christmas, so I only paid £7.50.

Is it cheesy American crap?  Yes.  I have played the intro and got to say that this cheesy pile of turd is actually pretty enjoyable.  Not sure why, it's just kind of fun and funny.  

I absolutely do not see this opening up in to some masterpiece of a game but it's whacky and fun and I'm pleasantly surprised.   

Are mashed up bodies with tiddies out strewn around everywhere and getting my face smashed with a cosh really necessary?  Absolutely.  I'll give it that, it does give me a few laughs.

Was probably worth £7.50 just for the hour of fun I had with it tonight.  It's a pretty easy recommend.

Oh and the OST got some bangers too.

Constraints:
- Length: 100 to 140 words
- Mention exactly 2 positive points and 1 negative point

- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
203 hours. 100% achievements. Worth every second.

Cyberpunk 2077 is pure style and soul. Neon-soaked streets, killer music, insane atmosphere. Night City feels alive, dangerous, funny, and way too real sometimes.

The story goes hard. Keanu Reeves as Johnny Silverhand is iconic, and Phantom Liberty is on another level. Reed (Idris Elba) steals the show with full spy-thriller energy. That DLC alone is wild.

The side quests are where this game really shines. Weird, emotional, unhinged, and memorable. Dialogue choices actually matter and let you be whoever you want to be. No two moments feel the same.

Cyberpunk 2077 is bold, creative, chaotic, and unforgettable. Leaving Night City after 203 hours felt like saying goodbye to something special. <3

Review:
completion:
Masterpiece of a Game ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

I’ve poured 252 hours into Elden Ring and can proudly say I’ve defeated every single boss, including the secret optional one. This isn’t just a game—it’s an experience, a sprawling RPG that perfectly balances challenge, freedom, and storytelling.

From the hauntingly beautiful world design to the sheer depth of combat, every corner of the Lands Between feels purposeful. Exploration is endlessly rewarding, whether you’re uncovering hidden dungeons, secret NPC quests, or massive optional bosses that test your skills to the limit.

The gameplay is tight, responsive, and endlessly versatile—you can experiment with builds, weapons, and magic to tackle challenges in countless ways. The lore is rich and cryptic, encouraging curiosity and rewarding those who pay attention to every detail.

In my opinion, Elden Ring sets a new standard for open-world RPGs. It’s punishing, yes, but every victory feels earned and every discovery feels magical. Few games leave such a lasting impression, and this one will stay with me for years to come.

Absolute must-play. One of the best RPGs I’ve ever experienced.

completion:
Cyberpunk is in another league. This is one of these games we'll all look back on as a major event in the history of gaming. If you are a discerning individual of high taste, this game is preem. I cannot recommend it enough!
- It's like GTA in the near alternate future.
- The level of immersion pushes forward the open world RPG genre. 
- Action was great, many ways to get things done leaving this game have an incredible amount of content in a single release, and the work continues with the expansions, fan mods, etc.
- Visuals are great, not much else to say these days for that. If on PC there's a lot of flexibility as you get up the hardware scale.
- This review is after 2.3, I played the update before and thought it was great too. 
- The story was enjoyable but went by too quickly! Or I wish it was longer, your choice. To new players interested I'd say if you want a really good experience you could spread out finishing all of the main missions and secondary missions.
- I can't emphasize how much this game just grabs hold of you. You'll be speaking in the Night City brainrot in no time. Enjoy every bit!

Review:
completion:
In All honesty the most B game ever made.  

There is so many good things; the music, the characters, Night City itself feels like its own person that breathes and moves.

The story I am not sold on and on top of that after all these years there are still bugs galore.  Missed music cues, enemies glitching out, awkward scripting.  I think there is a foundation where there is an A+ game but what is built right now is not it.  I think the sequal will be amazing and I believe that is where they will find their stride.  Phantom Liberty shows that.  

Overall I will give it a reccomend but pick it up on sale and make sure you get the DLC.

I played this quite a lot a long time ago. Came back once in a while. But after coming back one final time I can comfortably say that this game is not meant for casual play. It isn't. It is meant for folks who play this regularly. If you do not play this regularly, you will lose a lot and die a lot. You will feel useless and unable to really to anything noteworthy for your team, assuming you can leave spawn without dying.

I now understand why this game was plagued with bots way back when. It's an old game. Maybe it's time to move on.

Review:
completion: I've been playing Elden Ring for an embarrassingly long amount of time, and my friend suggested I give Cyberpunk 2077 a try. I looked at the videos of gameplay and was initially really turned off by the first person POV of the game. However, after playing for just a bit, I got pulled in by the story. Then I got pulled in by the rest of the game. Holy crap! To say this is my new favorite game would be quite an understatement and I can easily see myself sinking just as many, if not more, hours into this game as I have in Elden Ring so far. It's immersive, and I feel as though I am actually V, making these decisions in the game and surviving as I am. There are so many things that pull my attention that I sometimes feel like I suffer from some type of shiny object syndrome, but it's a good thing I think. Definitely not going to get bored any time soon! I'm only halfway through so far (I think) and still have so much left to do in this game, plus there are options for replayability with different build or paths to take. I'm going to spend a lot of time on this game.

Spawn. Buy armor. Peek corner. Pray.
Counter‑Strike 2 is CS’s sequel — classic 5v5 bomb mode, tactical depth, and flawless headshots (sometimes) — now rebuilt on the Source 2 engine with dynamic smoke, updated visuals, and global leaderboards. ()

It’s free to play and still one of the most played shooters on Steam, with massive competitive appeal and huge e‑sports momentum. The rounds are crisp, tense, and rewarding when you outsmart your opponent — but be ready for learning‑curve sweat and some internet chaos. 

Pros:

Tactical, rewarding gunplay that veterans live for 🎯 

Updated engine, graphics, and smoke mechanics 🔥 

Free‑to‑play with global leaderboards 📊 

Cons:

Cheaters and toxic lobbies still a thing 😅 

Some players report hit registration or performance frustrations ⚠️ 

Market/skin economy drama and skin‑price rollercoasters 💸 

Verdict:
The classic CS thrill evolved — still tense, still tactical, still free… but be ready for salt, sweat, and the occasional hacker.
Recommended (if you like competitive shooters).

Review:
completion:
My Love for Cyberpunk 2077

Cyberpunk 2077 is more than just a game to me; it is an experience that pulls me into a world full of emotion, chaos, and freedom. From the first moment I entered Night City, I felt connected to its atmosphere, characters, and story. The neon lights, futuristic technology, and deep choices make the game feel alive and unforgettable.

What makes Cyberpunk 2077 even more special is how it brings my friends and me together. My friends Cr0w, Smokey, and Tokyo all loved the game as much as I did. We spent hours talking about the storyline, our different choices, and our favorite characters. Each of us experienced the game in a unique way, yet we all shared the same excitement and passion for Night City.

The game also taught me how powerful storytelling in video games can be. Every mission feels meaningful, and the choices you make shape who you become in the game. Playing Cyberpunk 2077 with my friends made the experience even better, turning it into something we all remember and enjoy together.

In the end, Cyberpunk 2077 isn’t just a game I love—it’s a world I shared with my friends, and that’s what makes it truly special.

From the moment I started playing Cyberpunk 2077, I was captivated by its rich world and immersive storytelling. Despite having only about 82 minutes of initial playtime on PC—just to mod and transfer my saves to PlayStation—I’ve logged over 150 hours in the game. This truly speaks to how captivating and engaging the experience is.

Cyberpunk 2077 stands out as one of my top 10 favorite games of all time. The detailed world-building in Night City is unparalleled, with intricate narratives and complex characters that kept me hooked from start to finish. The freedom to explore and customize your experience is truly remarkable, and the modding community has only expanded the game’s potential, making it even more enjoyable.

What sets Cyberpunk 2077 apart is its blend of deep storytelling, breathtaking visuals, and a dynamic, living world. It’s a game that rewards exploration and creativity, and it’s easy to see why it’s become one of my all-time favorites.

In short, if you haven’t yet ventured into Night City, I highly recommend it. It’s a game that truly deserves a spot in any gamer’s top 10 list.

Review:
completion:
Not really my game. There was so much hype for this game, and the graphics [i]do[/i] look stunning, but the story is not really that interesting in my opinion. I appreciate the effort being put into giving cut-scenes more choices by allowing you to select the response to something another character says, but at the end it feels like whatever choice you made didn't really lead to a different outcome.

Sometimes I just want to sit back and enjoy the cut-scene.

I can't really describe it, but somehow, even though you are doing [i]more[/i] yourself in a cutscene, it feels very like a scripted scene. The game [i]wants[/i] you to walk to somewhere, only to get more dialog. It's like the game is telling you step by step how to progress, instead of treating you with a cinematic masterpiece that is a cutscene.

Cheers! Great redemption and probably the best single palyer game ever.

Review:
completion:
Elden Ring is one of the most impressive games I have ever experienced. The open world feels huge, alive, and full of mysteries. Every location is unique, beautifully designed, and invites you to explore. The atmosphere ranges from mystical and calm to dark and overwhelming and that’s exactly what makes the game so captivating.

The soundtrack is absolutely masterful. The music fits perfectly in every situation, whether during exploration, intense boss fights, or quiet moments. It enhances the mood, builds tension, and often creates pure goosebumps.

The bosses are another major highlight. They are creatively designed, challenging, and incredibly epic in their presentation. Every fight feels like a special event. The lore and story, which gradually unfold, add a lot of depth and make the world even more fascinating.

For me, Elden Ring comes incredibly close to being a perfect game. It’s very near to what I would call a truly flawless and outstanding experience.

Elden Ring is an absolute masterpiece full of atmosphere, excitement, and unforgettable moments. A clear recommendation.

Review:
completion:
50 hours in. 3 install/uninstall. Quitting the game for the final time for the same reason as the first couple times. The unskippable, monotonous, boring cutscenes and gameplay. I had about 20 minutes to play right now, loaded save game. Braindance. Oh, right. That's why I stopped playing before, because I didn't have time to waste. Alas here I am writing this review instead of playing. 

TLDR. It's okay. Melee is fun. Guns are unique and boring the same. Feel pretty good to shoot, especially as you level up and fine tune. But you'll quickly discover each playthrough/character is very specific. You use SMG on this guy. You use swords on this guy. You hack with this girl. Top all that off with the fact you can only respec your character once. Why? So I'm forced to play the awful story missions, again? 

The bugs are out of control. The crime system is still incredibly lame. Driving vehicles is, again, okay. This isn't an RPG. You can't do anything and be anyone. You are V, the person who will run the same boring mission and die the same way. Again. And again. 

PS: The Witcher 3 wasn't that great either. My how CDPR has changed.

Review:
completion:
It was fun overall. The challenge could be fun at times but didnt feel very rewarding

Some things I didn't like:
-Fighting through the world didnt feel challenging enough
-Aside from treasure, most open world loot didn't have much use
-Not enough human-like enemies. It feels boring to fight just a bunch of oversized masses that flop themselves at you
-Even the final boss wasn't gratifying at all in stage 2. It is just another blob that then uses mobility, distance and burst spells to cheese you

Other thoughts:
-Fights with bosses like Malenia, Crucible knights, Malekith were all enjoyable and the game needs more enemies and bosses of that style
-You might lose a lot of runes in Haligree if you are trying to loot everything like me
-If you are struggling, it is probably 1 of 2 things... 1) you are in an area that your levels simply arent ready for yet or 2) you haven't yet figured out how to min-max your DPS with weapons/abilities/spells yet

Final thoughts: I have played about 20% of the DLC and just don't feel compelled to continue. Due to the reasons above

GLHF

Constraints:
- Length: 100 to 140 words
- Mention exactly 2 positive points and 1 negative point
- Casual, honest tone

- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Recommended (Emotionally, Not Technically)

We’ve been playing this game for years. Years. Through patches, updates, metas, and whatever phase the devs are currently experimenting with. Loyalty has never been the issue.

The cheating system, however, very much has.

It would be fantastic — truly revolutionary — if at some point during this long, shared history, the developers decided to fix it. Not reinvent it. Not “improve detection over time.” Just… fix it. Cheaters remain a regular feature, and reporting often feels more ceremonial than effective.

The game itself is still fun, otherwise we wouldn’t still be here. But nothing kills enthusiasm faster than realizing skill, time, and effort are optional when someone else is running third-party software with zero consequences.

We’ll probably keep playing. We always do.

It would just be nice if fair play eventually joined us.
-SR

completion: Pretty good ngl, easiest for those trying to get into the souls series since it is my first souls (I've played all the others too and this is easily my favorite with 1000+ hours on console). The first playthrough should be blind or partially blind in case you get lost, other than that I recommend that you go for one type of build instead of spreading your stats across the board (Health > Stamina > Str/Dex/fai/Int). For the best experience (after your first run) imo is to run a basic straightsword or greatsword with nice shield and then try and learn all the bosses. It is extremely hard ofc but its honestly my favorite way to play since winning feels better than any other achievement in life. Just you, your sword, and your shield against this unfair world of monsters. Remember this if you feel like the worst player to touch a game... no human is able to beat these monsters in real life, that is the point, you are not human for you are the tarnished, chosen to defy death and come back to life and retry the bosses all over again, don't get greedy as the bosses never become slower, they never change their movesets or counters. Die.Learn.Destroy.

- Mention exactly 2 negative points and 1 positive point
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
The 'Meet your Match' update proved even a 9 year old game will succumb to the trend of matchmaking and force players to only play on Publisher servers. 

Instead of encouraging the individual to host their own servers or join others, Valve chooses to take the bandwidth and discourage community servers by filtering traffic. 
Where then players are greeted by bots, unbalanced teams or 10 minute matches that nobody gets to stay in after. The threat of bots is always alive as long as Valve continues to funnel the majority of tf2's playerbase into their own servers, where they do little to no moderation.

Valve should bring back the ability to select teams, in order to keep games balanced. Valve should also bring back the quickplay system. It kept both Valve servers and dedicated community servers populated. And matches within community servers are allowed to go on for hours, meaning you can play on the same map/gamemode to your heart's content.

Tf2, as a software, was developed by Valve, yes. But its very experience was developed by the community FOR the community. Don't let anyone tell you Valve can replicate it through their servers alone.

Review:
completion: This was my first FromSoft game, and probably one of my top ten games in general. Super fun once you get the hang of it, and I really really love delving into the lore of it all. Certainly a good start if you're looking to try a Souls game or soulslike, but don't know where to start. The open world aspect means you can leave and come back later if you feel stuck on a boss or area, so you aren't forced to fight something if you aren't having a great time. Of course, that doesn't mean it's easy; it's still a hard game, no matter where you go, but the option to go wherever you want (for the most part) makes it a fun experience. Also very fun to read messages from other people, and leave some of your own. Dog ahead :)

⭐ 9/10 – I Came for the Cyberware, Stayed for the Chaos ⭐

Cyberpunk 2077 is a neon-soaked, morally ambiguous playground where you can customize your implants, drive ridiculously fast cars, and somehow survive a city that seems determined to kill you in at least three creative ways per minute.

The world of Night City is breathtaking — dense, vibrant, and packed with stories waiting to unfold. The characters are memorable, the quests are often hilarious or heartbreaking, and the main story is engaging enough to make you care about a bunch of people who are probably going to get cybered anyway.

Combat is slick, hacking feels satisfying, and the driving physics are… well, let’s say fun in a destructive way. The bugs exist, sure, but sometimes they’re so ridiculous you can’t help but laugh — like when a NPC phases through a wall while screaming existentially. Classic Cyberpunk.

If you enjoy open-world RPGs, absurd cybernetic enhancements, and a city that refuses to play nice, Cyberpunk 2077 delivers a wild, unforgettable experience.

Highly recommended. Upgrade everything, survive the chaos, and maybe don’t anger the mechs.

886 / 5.000
One of the most worthwhile games to play, not only because of its diverse gameplay with many character customization options, but also because of the music that evokes a certain feeling in the player, especially the song "I really want to stay at your house." The NPCs in the game interact with the player in a way that's not typical of other games. The Phantom Liberty DLC expansion clearly shows the difference between Night City and Dogtown. Some parts of the Edgerunner movie are also recreated in the game, such as "David's Jacket" and "Guts, Rebecca Shotgun." These are items you can obtain in the game thanks to scenes from the movie, which makes the characters even more important. Furthermore, the game's six endings offer players a multi-layered emotional experience. In short, Cyberpunk is a game worth trying and experiencing from many different perspectives.

Really good game!  It got excellent  immersion, very good story and mechanic that is both simple and fun to use. I'm most impressed with how lively the RPG look, they really nailed the voice acting and the subtle body language. I'm also very impressed with the feeling of vibrant future urban space that it gives when driving or walking trough the streets. 
It has a very good balance between scripted scenes and feeling of freed of where to go next. 

I would only mention two minor complaints:
- What you say doesn't seem matter match in the way of how things develop. It might give different response, but the outcome rarely differs. However, the RPGs got so much "spirit" in them most of the times I do not mind it. 
- The netrumner build is seems way to strong. I'm mean if you didn't have cameras hacking to lunch you forward in to enemies bases it would still be to much. But again, it is mostly fun either way.

With well over 200 hours of playing this MASTERPIECE of a game, I write this review for the sake of all people looking for a game to sit down and just marinate in it's glory. I originally bought this game for a good game to play. I was not expecting to be met with an absolute BANGER of an intro scene! After opening the first door to the first steps, I gazed upon the INCREDIBLE vastness of the map and literally said out loud "Crap! This is a big game. I'm gonna have to watch so many hours of lore videos its not even funny!" And BOY it did NOT disappoint. To wrap it up,  easily one of the greatest games I've ever played, PEAK Cutscenes, PEAK weapons, PEAK Bosses.

PS. You can get married to a puppet beauty and rule the night together. Totally Worth.

Review:
completion:
I'm frankly not sure how this game receives acclaim now despite it still being somewhat of a mess. Granted, most of the large issues such as crashes (Most of the time) or overall surface presentation have been resolved in due part to patches. However, I question whether or not this approach to game design is going to work out for studios when they can't even out develop a game from a decade ago or more. There are multiple arguments or conversations to be had about why the game shipped in such a state for the initial release, but it doesn't help everything has to be reworked and tacked on due to poor planning. Such additions don't feel natural personally and very awkward during a playthrough. 

I can at least praise the concept/art/music aspects of the game or even the general plot of the story, but interest just falls off for both areas so quickly after Act I. It would at least hold up in some regard if it played like an RPG, but a lot of times you are forced into doing whatever the scenario wants you to do. This is also strained by the fact that a lot of the time this feels like it wants to be more of a movie or some single-track amusement ride on rails than a game.

Going into this game I had some high expectations, and I am proud to say that it surpassed them all. This game by all means has some issues because pretty much no game out there is flawless. Some bosses suck, some things are buggy, "Quests" are kinda fucked because they're very easy to miss or fuck up blind, and balance is absolutely horrible (You're kinda forced to balance your power and enemy scaling yourself). But generally? This game is one hell of a masterpiece.

It has:
- Some incredible bosses
- Great music
- No story (No, really, it doesn't exist), amazing lore (that you will not comprehend without watching a video but sure)
- Stunning map full of really cool places to explore
- Peak character voice acting

Genuine Frompeakware material, 100%'ed the game, no regrets. Play it. 11/10

Review:
completion:
After 500 hours and countless playthroughs (modded and unmodded alike), i can confidently say Elden RIng is the best game i've ever played and it really isn't close. the environments are genuinely stunning and awe-inspiring, and the atmosphere set by the narrative is palpable. this is a game for capital G gamers--it's hard, but fair. soulslikes aren't for everyone, but if you enjoy rewarding and satisfying gameplay, this is the best there is.
(and it's got all the dark fantasy/mythological lore you could ever hope for!)

the only minor drawback for this game applies to all From games, which is that you're pretty much locked at 60 fps if you want to play the game as intended--which can be jarring.

Review:
completion:
A World That Pulls You In...
Hours Played: 21.4 hrs (at time of review)
Recommended? 👍 Yes

After 21.4 hours, I can confidently say Elden Ring is one of the most immersive experiences I’ve had in gaming. The world feels alive — every corner hides something worth discovering, whether it’s a new boss, a hidden dungeon, or just breathtaking scenery. The combat is punishing but fair, and every victory feels earned.
What really stands out is the freedom: you’re never forced down a single path. I’ve spent hours just exploring, finding my own way, and still feel like I’ve only scratched the surface. The sense of scale and mystery keeps me hooked, and I’m loving every moment.
If you enjoy challenging combat, deep lore, and a world that rewards curiosity, Elden Ring is absolutely worth it.

Review:
completion:
I played a 158 RL Dex Build with taunters tongue active.

Here is my opinion on ELDEN RING.

Pros:

1. The Great Katana, especially with Cold infusion and Chilling Mist
2. The lore
3. The cutscenes (+the voice acting)
4. A few of the bosses like Messmer or Mohg
5. Some of the scenery

Cons:

1. The open world feels useless and way too big.
2. You need to grind materials/runes for everything.
3. Bosses are spammed and copy-pasted across the world, besides they just feel unfair, delaying their attacks too much and being way too fast in their attack outcome.
4. Bosses like Promised Consort or Malenia aren’t hard, they’re just overwhelming in their animations (I can’t see sh*t in that 2nd phase) and the sheer amount of attacks they throw at you.
5. Torrent dies everywhere, anytime. 
6. The camera just sucks, especially in fights with big bosses.
7. Invaders are either other casuals you beat in just a few seconds (20%) or some toxic little sh*theads, who can only win with their skilless twink gear (80%).

DARK SOULS III > ELDEN RING

completion:
Open world is way too big and has barely anything worthwhile in it

Bosses like to waste your time with 15 sec combos with barely any punish windows as well as having straight up unreactable attacks

Whack balancing in terms of equipment (why would an int character use anything other than moonveil)

Exploration feels unrewarding with so many rewards being spirit ashes, crafting items or useless consumables

Game tends to reuse its content way too much

If you visited 1 type of an optional area (catacombs, mines, etc) than you visited 99% of others, the main difference being the loot you find in them (which is worthless most of the time)

The worst camera in any of the fromsoft games ive played (especially bad on big enemies)

Lock on targeting is way worse than in previous titles

Bad hitboxes (especially on the big enemies)

Sleep inducing mounted combat

Schizophrenic NPC quests

Max lvl weapon upgrades are still limited per playthrough

Left-handed weapons are still limited to only r1s

Technical issues (game randomly stutters/drops frames for no reason)

Abysmal netcode

completion: The first gameplay from 2018 looks very interesting. When the game released in 2020, I was disappointed, but I finished it all. Now that they've released many patches and updates, as well as DLC, I decided to replay the game, collecting the preset during my first playthrough, and now I see they've changed the weapons and scripts. Previously, I could feel like a netrunner annihilating everything my demon could reach, but now hacking is a joke: you either don't kill anything or overclock yourself so you have 1 HP left to shoot the enemy. Overall, I'm disappointed. I'm a big fan of this theme and genre, but they've made the game worse and unplayable.

Write a review for the game "Team Fortress 2".

Constraints:
- Length: 100 to 140 words
- Mention exactly 2 negative points and 1 positive point
- Casual, honest tone

- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
In its current state, I cannot recommend Team Fortress 2. To anyone.

I love this game, I've loved this game since I started playing it, but the only real way to play it now is to join the very limited amount of community servers with specific rulesets that aren't the vanilla game or don't run the standard maps in rotation.

Valve has left the game in a borderline unplayable state since Meet Your Match released and have done little to nothing to fix it. Casual mode (and by extension Competitive mode) are horribly buggy messes that should have never been introduced into the game. A matchmaking system is entirely antithetical to what Team Fortress 2 is; a casual pick-up put-down first person shooter. Until this issue is addressed, my review will remain negative.

#YouWillNotPlay

completion:
I played DOTA 2 back on the WarCraft 3 days.  I wasn't an addict then.  Fasft forward to DOTA 2 release, I resisted playing.  Eventually my son asked to play a game that sounded to me like DOTA.  I been addicted ever since, and he's been playing since he was 6 years old.  The new patch I thought is a great way to freshen the game.  I hope they do radical changes like this every year to keep people into the game.   I see quite a few negative reviews.  Anyone who wants no change but is willing to play for 30 years can go back and play the WC3 with the mod, that thing is frozen in time forever.

I have to admit the game is starting to wane with me too, but thats not because of the changes.  Its hard to keep up with the game trends to remain relevant in playing.  

Kudos to the makers of DOTA 2., keep evolving!

Review:
completion:
Ive only been playing this game for about a year, and I absolutely adore and love it to death. 

From the game itself, to the community creations (SFMs, cosmetics) I find a deep inspiration that no other game provides.

When I first joined, it was constantly emphasized how I was “late to the party” because this game lacks proper updates for over seven years now. But I still find myself incredibly attached and involved. TF2 is the kind of game that doesn’t need updates to live on, and is instead propelled forward by the community around it. This game has a lot of fight in it and an even bigger army of fans behind it. I hope to see it prosper on now and in the far future.

Love you all, and thanks for all the summer crates.

This isn't like The Division or something where you can't take on high level enemies just because they are high level. Sure, you can't take on a gang of upper level enemies but one or two you'll be ok against even at lower levels. That said, you will die quite a bit early on if you are a rush in and start brawling type like my character is.  However, know what type of build you are going for before starting the game. 

I'll update my review when I've completed the game.

Review:
completion:
It took me almost hundred hours to actually reach the Embers. And i would wait longer if i knew how it'll turn out, because all the jokes around the Internet are actually truthful. If i could go back in time — i would.

The Cyberpunk world became something truly important for me, even with all the bugs, even if it couldn't make me cry, but this game became such an important piece of my life. I dreamed of playing it years ago, waited actual months to get my hands on it. First few days i couldn't do anything besides it and those few weeks were insane. I played almost daily and that's the reason i regret going to the Embers.

I felt like there is still time, one more gig here, another mission there and that is still will be time to finish the game, but i rushed it — went to the Hanako and finished the main story. And after the ending, even when i'm back to the NC — it's no longer the same city. 

I love Night City for it's aesthetics, seeing the centre for the first time felt to like being a child, having the whole world to discover. But still, as much as i love it, i have it's rotten guts.

I don't want to be forgotten too. Not in this big city, not in this big world.

- Length: 100 to 140 words

- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Really enjoy the game. I play it on a laptop not meant for gaming and so there was the added difficulty of a pretty bad pc port which has very slow input lag and control drift, in addition to stuttering and whatnot, but enemies and bosses are mostly doable as long as they are predictable. Once I got a controller, everything became much easier due to more responsive controls and whatnot, even on this potato laptop.

Some critiques:
1. Some of the level and arena designs are quite poor in that they present difficulties unrelated to the game mechanics but are purely technical such as giant bosses in tiny arenas which lead to cameras constantly clipping into the walls and the boss itself
2. These poor design issues combine with poor controls to create situations where you are really fighting against your own PC and camera rather than the boss itself, which can be a challenge in itself but not the enjoyable point of this game.

All in all, still a very enjoyable game with an actual challenge.

prompt:

Write a review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".
Target rating: 9/10.

Constraints:
- Length: 100 to 140 words
- Mention exactly 2 positive points and 1 negative point
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
I first purchased CP2077 when it came out, spent 15 minutes ingame and was heavily disappointed, I felt like I had been scammed. I googled my concerns, found that there were many others like me. I refunded the game, and never looked back.

Until now. Man, what a comeback. What a STORY. I played 80% of the game in vanilla 2.3, and THEN I modded it and WOW. It's like an entirely different game both times. There's a ton of depth, a ton of different ways to play. Stealth? Done. Shoot em' up? Done. Cars? Weapons? Almost unending variations, then mods will add even more if you wish. Every time I turn down an alleyway I haven't explored, I find something new to do. 

The story progresses at a rate that gives you a chance to relish in a feeling or a mood, but still moves along fast enough that you can spend an hour each evening and feel like you accomplished something.

Just buy it if you haven't tried it, and if you like it as much as I did, there's an expansion that added almost an entirely new main story worth of content. 

I am pleased with CDPR and the efforts they took to fix the game, and I am VERY excited for a sequel.

Write a review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".
Target rating: 9/10.

Constraints:
- Length: 100 to 140 words
- Mention exactly 2 positive points and 1 negative point
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
I'll start by saying that I'm not the type of person to play through the same game twice, very rarely do I even buy the same game for multiple platforms. As of writing this, I'm playing through Cyberpunk 2077 for the fifth time across Xbox and Steam. It is that good.

The gameplay and customization is great. You really can go at most scenarios however you wish, be it stealth, guns blazing, turning enemies on each other, or even charging in with a plastic meat stick. There's a solid perk system that allows you to create some interesting, highly specialized builds.

The story is well written and entertaining, even the side missions and filler tasks have their own little stories that occasionally tie into the overall plot. I have found myself actually getting lost reading logs and listening to dialogues just to see some of those webs that the writers at CDPR created.

The setting and visuals are amazing. There's a reason this game has been used as a benchmark over the last five years, but beyond that, it truly is something to see the neon filled, futuristic dystopia that is Night City.

Review:
completion:
Man, what a ride

After playing KCD2, Expedition 33 and Elden ring in the same year, my bar was really high, and Cyberpunk passed it with no problems.

The writing for both main storyline and side quests is really good, make you care about the setting and the people you meet throughout Night City. Just to get slapped in the face by the dark reality of this hellhole.

Game is either mid lenght or long, depending how much side stuff you want to do. Which is very welcome after having to spend 120 hours to beat Elden Ring.

Optimization is great, my rig is nothing to wow at, with an RTX 3050 and a 10 year old CPU. Im running constant 60fps on mid-high settings and it still looks great. 

Strongly recommend playing with mods, to add some QoL and immersion things

Review:
completion:
I don't support Easy Anti-Cheat at all. Terrible anti-cheat. Good thing that with minimal effort you can just say no to EAC, and with about the same minimal effort you can install a simple mod to do better coop than was available in the base game. Unfortunately, the fact that I refuse to deal with EAC means my review may be tainted by my respect for my computer, so bear this in mind...
The game is utterly beautiful. Nobody is shocked by this, but even on low graphics, the game looks amazing. The gameplay, too, is fun. It's tense, and it can be frustrating when you die at a bad time, but overall I quite enjoy it.
I hear the story is incredible, but I was spoiled with half of it years ago and the friends I play with want to skip cutscenes (having played the game several times), so I really don't experience it too often. Though, what I do experience is interesting.
That said, the game is sometimes unstable. I wouldn't bring this up on my [i]modded experience[/i], but I've heard from almost everyone I talk to that the base game is [i]worse[/i] on this front. I'm not sure how, but it's something to be considered.

completion:
A supreme achievement in the land of gaming. 
This game does not revolutionize story-writing, gameplay, cinematography, open-world, RPG systems, and many other elements it contains, but it certainly excels in each one of them, providing a product of life-changing quality. Its story is amongst the best ever written, in general. 
The game is not without flaws, as nothing is, but they're so minor, they turn bleak when compared with everything else that's being presented on the table. Yes, the police system is still a bit shallow, yes occasional bugs still appear, although the game has been fixed in a major scale; yes you still cannot romance Takemura, but all of that falls apart under the weight of its positives. 
There is only a small number of games that deserve such high praises, but Cyberpunk 2077 will surely stand the test of time as one of them. One could say - Cyberpunk will [i] [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AN1RJF55NXI&list=RDAN1RJF55NXI&start_radio=1] Never Fade Away. [/url] [/i]
10/10

Constraints:
- Length: 100 to 140 words

Review:
completion:
I don't need to tell you that Elden Ring is a marvel of game design. There will, for better or worse, probably never be another game like it. I have never inhabited a world so deeply considered and detailed than the Lands Between, each step you take carries with it the footsteps of generations past. It's beautiful! If you care for a world with layers upon layers of history and civilization, Elden Ring is a tasty fuckin meal. Of course, as always, From's combat is top-notch. 
It is not a perfect game, but it is truly, truly magical for your first playthrough. My gripes are common refrains too - too many repeated enemies and bosses, the world is a little too big for its own good. Comes together to deserve every last bit of praise it gets, though.

Review:
completion:
Night City: bright lights, big guns, and even bigger feelings.

Cyberpunk 2077 is a sprawling open‑world RPG where you wander, shoot, hack, flirt, and occasionally get shot while looking fabulous in leggings with neon spikes. Once notorious for being a buggy mess at launch, years of patches and expansions have turned it into a very positive experience loved by a huge playerbase — with lots of story, choices, and post‑launch improvements still drawing crowds every night. 

Pros:

Deep Night City with tons to do and explore 🌆 

Strong story & memorable characters (Phantom Liberty adds even more) 🧠 

Still huge, still popular — even years later with a very positive Steam rating 📊 

Cons:

Not perfect — bugs and odd behaviors still crop up sometimes 🪲 

RPG mechanics and some systems can feel a bit uneven depending on playstyle 

Verdict:
From disaster at launch to beloved cyberpunk RPG, this is now one of the most talked‑about open‑world games out there. Recommended if you like story‑driven RPGs and neon‑soaked chaos — especially on sale. 🎮

Review:
completion:
Absolute masterpiece.  
I had never played a CDProjectRed game before, so have no fanboy memories of the witcher etc etc. 

But Cyberpunk absolutely blew me away with every minute of gameplay.
The world, the combat, the music, the driving, the missions, the sheer amount of content.  

Were there small bugs and glitches? Sure. Did I care? No. Because the rest of the experience genuinely blew my mind so much that I belived for 95% of my playtime - I was a merc in night city. 

I guess one of my biggest 'fears' of this game was my belief that they would use Keanu as a 'star attraction' -  but his character and his story are written so well, that he feels like his own solid identity.

Anyways - If a rich story, great open world with lots of unique missions, stupid amounts of replayability , fantastic voice acting and animations, absolutely sick and FUN to play unique builds interests you, get this game.  After the first five hours, you'll be hooked. 

Thanks to all the dev's who worked on this - Your passion for this game showed in every single minute I lived in Night City.

- Length: 100 to 140 words

Review:
completion:
I never could get a grasp on souls-likes before Elden Ring. They always frustrated me because you couldn't do anything except bang your head against the same wall (boss) until you defeat it and hit the next wall, or stop playing. 

This is the first souls-like I completed. The #1 thing that let me stick it out was the fact that there is always something else to do if you find a boss you can't deal with at the moment. The #2 thing that really made me fall in love was the fact you can be a true tank despite the purists poo-pooing that playstyle. 

There's also nothing wrong with throwing in an mod making you very overpowered, because experiencing the sense of wonder the game provides is plenty worth it. I got my friend to play with me in the co-op mod, and even with his absolute hatred towards souls-likes he proceeded to fall in love just as I did. 

It still has classic, chunky, weighty combat that takes a bit of getting used to. But once I got a hang of it, it allowed me to transition to other souls games and have a much better time understanding the language of the game (even if I haven't beaten most of them. The linear nature of the other ones still drives me nuts).

Write a review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".
Target rating: 9/10.

Constraints:
- Length: 100 to 140 words
- Mention exactly 2 positive points and 1 negative point
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion: Without mods, they've done great. Story and world building are solid, characters are interesting, gameplay is well developed for all playstyles. There's an insane amount to do for completionists and most of it doesn't feel too tedious. For second playthroughs the act 1 skip makes good choices and sets you up well. Wish they had more than just one character reset but that's really negligeable. Romance options in the vanilla game are also kinda bland with Panam being the only sane choice. With mods this is one of the best powerfantasies on market. Become a cyberninja, chromejock, or netrunning god. Enjoy extra gigs and streets of chaos. Play a visually fantastic first person experience however you like. The community is great and a good portion of the collections on nexus are pretty thoroughly tested for something that's free. When it says easy install they mean it.

Review:
completion: Cyberpunk 2077 was a game I dismissed at launch. Overwhelming negative reports, all the videos of the  bugs and glitches. so I never touched it, until I caved and watched Edgerunners (well over a year after the anime aired) which reignited my curiosity, and when I finally stepped into the game, I was stunned by how much it had evolved, and how much it wasn't all the negative things I thought it'd be. What once seemed like a cautionary tale of hype now felt like a living, breathing world transforming it from something I ignored into one of my most cherished gaming experiences.

prompt:

Write a review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".
Target rating: 3/10.

Constraints:
- Length: 100 to 140 words
- Mention exactly 2 negative points and 1 positive point
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Just play GTAV again instead. 

Questlines are all the same exact story:
- You or someone else has a problem
- You find people that can help you solve the problem
- You get warned they will betray you
- You get betrayed
- GUESS THATS JUST NIGHT CITY!

On top of that there is nothing to do in this game outside of driving/fighting while doing missions. There are arcades everywhere, but no games, unless you count the Chrome offline Dinosaur game as a deep/interesting minigame. I found a pool table once that I could interact with and got super excited... only to find out the interaction was just a single time animation. 

Until you get to the DLC content the side content is worse than GTA3 tbh. You just show up at locations and sneak by or kill everyone. 

Music is good
Combat feels good

I really really really wanted to like this game. I had been hyped for it since the very first trailer years upon years ago. I only put off playing it because I wanted to make sure it was stable and all the DLC was out. Sadly it still isn't stable as I probably crashed 50+ times over a 75 hour playtime and ran into various bugs all over the place.

Review:
completion:
Cyberpunk 2077 is an absolutely awesome game — easily one of the best I’ve ever played.

Beyond the wonderful and deeply immersive gameplay, what truly elevates it is the philosophical core. The game doesn’t just show a futuristic city; it explores where humanity might be heading. Corporations, AI, the Blackwall, transhumanism, Soulkiller — all of it ties into unsettling questions about identity, consciousness, and what it really means to be human.

The idea of copying a mind, losing the self, or existing as something almost human creates a genuine existential tension that sticks with you long after you stop playing. Night City feels alive, oppressive, beautiful, and tragic all at once.

This isn’t just an action RPG — it’s a story about humanity facing its own reflection in technology. An unforgettable experience.

Review:
completion:
One of the best games I have ever played.

The heroes (playable characters) are unlocked from the beginning & each of them have unique skills. It is the same map for every game but each game fells different. The different hero combos, item builds, laning strategies make each game really fun & unique. The tutorials make the basic mechanics easy to understand.

But this game is only recommended for those with great patience, time, energy & good multitasking skills. It takes time to master. It has a fairly steep learning curve but can be enjoyed by all. The community can be toxic & stupid sometimes.

The game gets regular balance changes.

Review:
completion:
A neat multi-purpose game that is not just a Class-based Shooter game (Or it's also called Hero Shooter, I believe?..), but it also works as great Chat Room game. With all these voice lines, taunt animations, killbinds, ragdolls and bugs, that became crucial part of the game. There's a reason it's fans still root and fight for it for over a decade at this point. Even if there's quite a few more hero shooters nowadays, they can't achieve the style and communicability of TF2. And even if, other big companies won't go for it anyways, they only wanted the competitive part.
In other words, there probably won't be any kind of game that would somehow replace it, probably not even from indie devs. Maybe I'll be proven otherwise ten years later, but... who knows, who knows...

prompt:

Write a review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".
Target rating: 9/10.

Constraints:
- Length: 100 to 140 words
- Mention exactly 2 positive points and 1 negative point
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
From Buggy Mess to Absolute Masterpiece

I played through the entire game at launch in 2020. Back then, with all the bugs and awful optimization, the only thing I could really praise was the story - and even that felt hard to appreciate through all the crashes.

Cyberpunk 2077 is now a legit 10/10. After years of patches and polish, this is finally the game we were supposed to get. The story is still incredible - dark, heavy, with choices that actually made me sit and think. The characters feel real and stay with you long after you finish. This is "mature" in the best way - not just edgy violence and sex, but genuinely thoughtful storytelling about life, death, and what it means to be human.

And Phantom Liberty? Absolute banger. Seriously one of the best expansions I've ever played.

I've done 100% completion now. Not a single regret about any hour I spent in Night City. If you skipped this at launch like most people, now's your chance. CDPR really pulled off the comeback.

Highly recommended.

Review:
completion:
I've played Cyberpunk on it's initial release back in 2020. And even though I did not have that much performance issues, I had a lot of expectations that weren't met. So back then I would rate it 7/10. Decent game, nice world, but with a lot of unfulfilled potential. 

Now, 5 years later, and with the Phantom Liberty DLC, I thought: let's give it another go. Did not regret. I can't describe how pristine and alive this world feels. Mind you, I've never enjoyed a game more on replay than the first playthrough, but this time it's definitely more fun. It's immersive, the story is good, just doing your own thing in Night City feels good, naturally even, and there's so much to do that does not feel like a grind or repetitive at all. 

It's insane to me to see how much has changed for the better. CD Projekt Red, I take my hat off. Game's a 10/10 without question now.

Therefore, for me, this game deserves 5 stars!

This is got to be one of the BEST games i've played, the story, the soundtrack, the game itself, absolute perfection, i've dismissed Cyberpunk 2077 in the past for it's rocky launch, but damn if you play this game in 2025, you wont regret it.

Thank you CDPR for this masterpiece of a game. (and the anime too)

Review:
completion:
League of Legends but:

1.    Too zoomed in so you can't see whats happening. 
2a.  Stuns and silences that last literally 6 - 8 seconds to remove all chance of counter-play.
2b.  Because of this BKB is needed on 99% of all heroes, giving a few second window where you get to play.
3.    Hero speed is much faster and the map is much bigger, combined with point 1 and its constant panning.
4.    Jungle role is still not a thing, and the jungle is way less interesting.
5.    Hero balance is non-existent. heroes hard counter each-other. Games are decided in hero select.
6.    Somehow even a more toxic community.
7.    Items are less diverse, and it seems the only way they can develop interesting ones is to give them all 
       active abilities, making the game a memory game of what item is in what hotkey slot.
8.    Blink is still an expensive item you need to buy, forcing you to chose between mobility or power, making
        it impossible to play a hero that needs a blink in a losing lane.

completion: This game kind of builds on you. Act 1 is great, then act 2 feels a little convoluted for a bit, but then it starts to tie together really well. It's the same with your character build: at first it all feels generic, but then it starts building in whatever direction you take it, and a lot of different styles are viable. Strongly recommend getting phantom liberty with the game as it mixes up the middle part of the game a lot and has a strong plotline. As a whole, with the DLC, this is a great game. I bought it back at launch, and it was hard to get through. Now, it flows much better. The character writing can be hit or miss, but eventually all the characters grow on you, like real people. Strong RPG, just takes some patience to feel invested. Overall recommend.

I've had this game since launch (yes, since [i]then[/i], through all that fun stuff) on Xbox and I have recently started playing on PC. After five years, I stand by the contention that not only is this one of the best games that have been released this generation but it is a testament to what can be achieved when a studio is sufficiently motivated to do things right, even if the start isn't the greatest. 

Countless hours of play and exploration, trying different combinations of tools, weapons and cyberware, there isn't much this game doesn't deliver. Except an ending that doesn't leave you slightly depressed. But that's the cyberpunk genre for you. High tech, low life, and no real winners at the end of the day.

completion: I don't think any other game has made me feel in such a way that Cyberpunk 2077 made me feel. It has it's ups and downs, and it's a bit of a walking simulator, but the story more than makes up for it. The way that the player interacts with the main character and how V interacts with the world is metacognitive hell and I wouldn't have it any other way. The gameplay is fun as well, and there is always more than one way to do things. A phenomenal piece of art and I am looking forward to future playthroughs, even if they won't be as incredible as the first. Definitely pick this game up.
